# set up

## Parent folder

```{r}
message(getwd())
```

## Check params

```{r}
# add check function
stopifnot(file.exists(params$in_file))
cars = readRDS(params$in_file)
```

## Load data

```{r knitr-setup}
# Set seed for reproducibility
set.seed(1454944673)
library(knitr)

opts_chunk[["set"]](
    autodep = TRUE,
    bootstrap.show.code = FALSE,
    cache = params$cache_on,
    cache.lazy = params$cache_on,
    cache.path = params$cache_dir,
    dev = c("png", "pdf"),
    error = FALSE,
    fig.height = 7,
    fig.retina = 2,
    fig.width = 7,
    highlight = TRUE,
    message = FALSE,
    prompt = TRUE,
    # formatR required for tidy code
    tidy = TRUE,
    warning = FALSE)

```

```{r setup, message=FALSE}
# Load bcbioRNASeq object
# Directory paths
output_dir <- params$output_dir
dataDir <- file.path(params$output_dir, "data")
dir.create(dataDir, showWarnings = FALSE, recursive = TRUE)
```

## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
